oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Major W. D. Reynolds
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Miss Martha Brownlow, Or the Heroine of Tennessee

The Heroine of Tennessee : a truthful and graphic account of the many perils and privations endured by Miss Martha Brownlow, the lovely and accomplished daughter of the celebrated Parson Brownlow, during her residence with her father in Knoxville
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Booklet; the cover image is an illustration of Susan Browlow, daughter of William Gannaway "Parson" Brownlow.

This novel, written by Major W.D. Reynolds, tells the story of Susan's reputed saving of the U.S. flag which was flying over the home of her father, William Gannaway "Parson" Brownlow while Knoxville was controlled by the Confederates. Reynolds uses a pseudonym for Susan--Martha--possibly to protect her identity. Susan and her father travelled during the war selling their novels (he had his own) and making speeches about the defiant Unionists living in East Tennessee.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Women; United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865--Fiction
Capturing the Flag
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: McClung Historical Collection, Knox County Public Library
